column1: Change log: present and usable
column6: Change log is present and contains the required information (date, version, sections changed, summary of changes, reason, authors).
column9: Change log is present but inconsistent.

column1: Architecture: system context and components/connectors
column6: Clear system context (e.g., C4 L1–L2) with actors, containers/components, and labeled connectors/protocols.
column9: Major components/connectors shown; some labeling or clarity gaps.

column1: Architecture: boundaries and deployment assumptions
column6: Boundaries and deployment assumptions are stated explicitly and match the described architecture.
column9: Some boundaries/assumptions are implied but not fully stated.

column1: Architecture: diagram accessibility and labeling
column6: At least one well-labeled diagram with figure number, caption, and alt text.
column9: Diagram exists but figure/caption/alt text is incomplete.

column1: Interfaces/APIs and data contracts: inventory and coverage
column6: Key interfaces/APIs are identified with clear ownership/scope.
column9: Lists main interfaces but coverage is incomplete.

column1: Interfaces/APIs and data contracts: contracts and examples
column6: Contracts are formal or well-structured (OpenAPI/Proto/JSON Schema) with example requests/responses and common errors.
column9: Basic I/O descriptions and some schema details or examples.
column12: Little schema detail and no useful examples.

column1: Interfaces/APIs and data contracts: auth, versioning, and error handling
column6: Auth and versioning strategy explicit; error handling conventions are clear.
column9: Mentions error handling and either auth or versioning.

column1: Component design and responsibilities: decomposition and responsibilities
column6: Clear decomposition into components/services with responsibilities and boundaries.
column9: Main components described but responsibilities/boundaries may be fuzzy.

column1: Component design and responsibilities: dependencies and ops considerations
column6: Shows how components relate to interfaces/APIs and key dependencies; includes performance/scalability/ops considerations.
column9: Dependencies mentioned; ops considerations are light.

column1: Component design and responsibilities: component-specific risks linked
column6: 1–2 technical/integration risks are tied to components and linked to the risk register.
column9: Risks present but loosely tied.

column1: Technical and integration risk register: quantity and specificity
column6: Prioritized register with at least five project-specific technical/integration risks.
column9: At least three relevant risks.

column1: Technical and integration risk register: impact/likelihood and mitigation
column6: Each risk includes impact, likelihood, and mitigation/acceptance.
column9: Basic mitigation exists but impact/likelihood is uneven.

column1: Technical and integration risk register: linkage and system-level consolidation
column6: Risks consolidated and re-ranked into a system-level view with links to affected requirements/components/ADRs.
column9: Some links exist but consolidation/prioritization is partial.

column1: Decisions: decision documentation quality
column6: Key decisions documented with clear context and intended outcomes.
column9: Decisions listed with brief context.

column1: Decisions: alternatives, rationale, and consequences
column6: Includes alternatives considered, rationale, and consequences/tradeoffs.
column9: Some rationale provided; alternatives/tradeoffs light.

column1: Decisions: ADR linkage and adoption evidence
column6: Links to ADRs/decision notes with clear status and PR/issue links showing adoption.
column9: At least one ADR reference; implementation links partial.

column1: Visual clarity: diagram readability and consistency
column6: Diagrams legible and consistently labeled; naming/notation align between diagrams, text, and code.
column9: Diagrams generally readable; minor labeling inconsistencies.

column1: Traceability: mapping across artifacts
column6: Includes traceability aid mapping risks, requirements, components, and ADRs.
column9: Some traceability exists but is partial.

column1: Writing: structure and readability
column6: Concise, well-structured, polished; uses clear headings and bullets; stays close to the expected core length (~3–8 pages) while still being complete; figures/tables improve skimmability and understanding.
column9: Mostly clear with some structure; minor readability issues or slightly off-target length.

column1: Writing: professionalism and clarity
column6: Professional tone; claims are precise and easy to follow; interfaces, risks, and decisions use consistent formatting and are written in verifiable language (reader can tell what is being asserted and what evidence/artifact supports it).
column9: Generally clear; occasional ambiguity, inconsistent formatting, or awkward wording.
column12: Unclear or unprofessional tone; inconsistent or confusing formatting and claims.

column1: Writing: accessibility
column6: Figures/tables are legible with short captions; link text is descriptive; private links include lightweight screenshots/snippets so graders can evaluate. (Required architecture diagram alt-text/caption expectations are assessed in the architecture diagram rubric items.)
column9: Some accessibility practices are used; minor gaps (e.g., missing some captions, vague link text, or limited evidence for private links).
column12: Inaccessible formatting or evidence not evaluable (e.g., illegible figures, vague links, or private links with no accessible backup).
